frameworks.name: RTCO
frameworks.description: Role–Task–Context–Output: Define who the model is, what it must do, the background context, and the desired output format.
frameworks.example: Act as a UX researcher. Summarize user interviews into key themes in bullet format.

frameworks.name: CoT
frameworks.description: Chain of Thought: Encourage step-by-step reasoning to improve logical accuracy and transparency.
frameworks.example: Let's solve this step by step, explaining each reasoning step clearly before concluding.

frameworks.name: ReACT
frameworks.description: Reason + Act: Alternate between reasoning and taking actions or making observations.
frameworks.example: Thought: user wants higher engagement. Action: suggest A/B testing strategy.

frameworks.name: TACT
frameworks.description: Task–Action–Context–Tone: Define what to do, how to do it, the background info, and the desired style.
frameworks.example: Task: Write product description. Action: Focus on benefits. Context: Luxury skincare brand. Tone: Elegant and persuasive.

frameworks.name: TREE
frameworks.description: Think–Reason–Explain–Evaluate: A framework for reflective reasoning and justification.
frameworks.example: Think about the causes, reason through possible outcomes, explain your logic, and evaluate the best answer.

frameworks.name: CRAFT
frameworks.description: Context–Role–Ask–Format–Tone: A framework to align the model’s role, purpose, and output format.
frameworks.example: Context: Writing for sustainability blog. Role: Journalist. Ask: Draft article. Format: 3 sections. Tone: Neutral.

frameworks.name: Prompt Sandwich
frameworks.description: Instruction–Input–Reinforcement: Restate the task before and after the data to reduce drift.
frameworks.example: Instruction: Summarize. Input: Article text. Reinforcement: Keep summary under 100 words.

frameworks.name: CRISPE
frameworks.description: Context–Role–Input–Steps–Parameters–Execution: A complete structured prompting format for clarity and control.
frameworks.example: Context: Academic summary. Role: Research assistant. Steps: Identify key arguments. Parameters: 200 words max.

frameworks.name: CoT+SC
frameworks.description: Chain-of-Thought + Self-Consistency: Generate multiple reasoning paths and choose the most logical answer.
frameworks.example: Explore 3 possible solutions, compare reasoning, and select the most consistent answer.

frameworks.name: RAP
frameworks.description: Role–Audience–Purpose: Simplifies communication tasks to focus on message alignment.
frameworks.example: Role: Marketing strategist. Audience: Startup founders. Purpose: Explain storytelling value.

frameworks.name: ICED
frameworks.description: Instruction–Context–Example–Desired Output: Ensures clarity and consistency using explicit examples.
frameworks.example: Instruction: Write a press release. Context: Product launch. Example: 'Apple announces...'. Desired Output: 3 paragraphs.

frameworks.name: MAPP
frameworks.description: Motivation–Action–Parameters–Product: Links purpose with execution in creative or strategic prompts.
frameworks.example: Motivation: Improve investor decks. Action: Analyze slides. Parameters: Focus on clarity. Product: Improvement list.

frameworks.name: DIET
frameworks.description: Data–Instruction–Example–Type: Ideal for analytical tasks using structured data.
frameworks.example: Data: Sales table. Instruction: Identify top regions. Example: 'North America: +12%'. Type: Bullet summary.

frameworks.name: SCQA
frameworks.description: Situation–Complication–Question–Answer: A narrative reasoning framework for structured storytelling.
frameworks.example: Situation: Sales down. Complication: Competition up. Question: Why? Answer: Weak retention strategy.

frameworks.name: APE
frameworks.description: Ask–Process–Evaluate: Simple reasoning pattern for analytical responses.
frameworks.example: Ask: What's best platform? Process: Compare options. Evaluate: Choose one with reasoning.

frameworks.name: PEEL
frameworks.description: Point–Evidence–Explain–Link: Structured writing for clarity and persuasion.
frameworks.example: Point: AI saves time. Evidence: Automates tasks. Explain: Frees creative effort. Link: Increases productivity.

frameworks.name: PAIR
frameworks.description: Persona–Action–Input–Response: Used for conversational agents and dialogue structure.
frameworks.example: Persona: Customer support rep. Action: Handle complaints. Input: 'Item broken'. Response: Apologize and offer refund.

frameworks.name: RAISE
frameworks.description: Role–Audience–Intent–Steps–Expectation: Ideal for instructional or educational writing.
frameworks.example: Role: Teacher. Audience: Beginners. Intent: Explain AI. Steps: Define, Illustrate, Apply. Expectation: Clear summary.

frameworks.name: FEARS
frameworks.description: Format–Examples–Audience–Role–Style: Controls stylistic alignment and tone.
frameworks.example: Format: Tweet thread. Examples: @SahilBloom style. Audience: Founders. Role: Growth coach. Style: Smart, concise.

frameworks.name: CUP
frameworks.description: Clarity–Usefulness–Personality: Framework for evaluating and improving text quality.
frameworks.example: Review output for clarity, usefulness, and human tone.

frameworks.name: LEAP
frameworks.description: Learn–Evaluate–Apply–Produce: Reflective structure for synthesis and improvement.
frameworks.example: Learn from feedback. Evaluate patterns. Apply insights. Produce improved version.

frameworks.name: GROW
frameworks.description: Goal–Reality–Options–Way Forward: Coaching and goal-oriented reasoning structure.
frameworks.example: Goal: Improve prompts. Reality: Lacking structure. Options: Study frameworks. Way Forward: Build library.

frameworks.name: DEEP
frameworks.description: Define–Explore–Evaluate–Present: Analytical flow for structured reasoning or reports.
frameworks.example: Define the issue, explore causes, evaluate solutions, and present conclusions.

frameworks.name: SCOR
frameworks.description: Situation–Challenge–Options–Recommendation: Used for strategic analysis and executive summaries.
frameworks.example: Situation: User churn rising. Challenge: Poor onboarding. Options: Improve flow, offer tutorials. Recommendation: Redesign onboarding.
